prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it impossible to get a home loan with a poor credit history after a divorce?[/INST]
pred:
Hello! I'm here to help you understand your options for getting a home loan with a poor credit history after a divorce. While it's true that a poor credit history can make it more challenging to qualify for a home loan, it's not impossible. Here are some factors to consider:

1. Time is on your side: After a divorce, your credit history may have taken a hit, but with time, your score will start to improve as long as you make timely payments on your debts. Give yourself some time (about 2-3 years) before applying for a home loan to allow your credit score to recover.
2. Consider alternative lenders: Traditional lenders may be hesitant to approve a home loan for someone with a poor credit history after a divorce, but there are alternative lenders who specialize in providing home loans to borrowers with less-than-perfect credit. These lenders may offer more flexible terms and lower credit score requirements.
3. Take steps to improve your credit score: If you're serious about buying a home soon, focus on improving your credit score. This can involve catching up on overdue bills, paying off outstanding debts, and avoiding any new derogatory marks on your credit report. You can also consider working with a credit counselor or financial advisor to help you navigate the process
answers: No, it is never impossible to get credit so long as there are no price controls or quotas. In most of the United States, the impetus for housing is so strong that it's one sector of credit that has nearly no price regulation, price in this case being interest rates. Corporate banks will not touch you now because Dodd-Frank now makes them liable to you and investors if you default on the mortgage.  Also, Fannie & Freddie, who ultimately finance most mortgages in the US now require banks to buy back loans if they fail, so banks are only financing the most creditworthy. All is not lost because markets are like rivers if not fully dammed: they find a way through. In your case, you can get a fully-financed mortgage if you're willing to pay interest rates probably double what you could otherwise get in the market with good credit. If the foreclosure process is quick and benefits the lender more in your state, the interest rate will be even lower. Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How fast does the available amount of gold in the world increase due to mining?[/INST]
pred:
The available amount of gold in the world can increase through mining, but the rate at which it increases depends on various factors, including the number of gold mines operating, the level of production at these mines, and the grades of the ore being mined.

According to the World Gold Council (WGC), global gold mining output has been growing steadily over the past few decades, with an average annual increase of around 1-2% per year. However, this growth rate has slowed in recent years due to declining ore grades and increasing costs.

In 2020, the global gold mining industry produced around 3,400 tonnes of gold, up from 3,200 tonnes in 2019. This represents a growth rate of around 5%. However, it's worth noting that gold mining output has been declining in some regions, such as South Africa, while it has been growing in others, such as China and the United States.

The rate at which gold mining output grows can also be influenced by geopolitical factors, such as changes in government policies or economic conditions. For example, in 2020, gold mining output in Russia decreased due to a decline in gold production caused by a combination of factors, including the impact of COVID-19 and geopolitical tensions.
answers: Approximately 5.3 billion ounces have been mined. This puts the total value of all gold in the world at about $9.5 trillion, based on $1800/oz. Total world net worth was $125T in 2006. There's an odd thing that happens when one asset's value is suddenly such a large percent of all assets. (This reminds me of how and why the tech bubble burst. Cisco and EMC would have been worth more than all other stocks combined if they grew in the 00's like they did in the 90's.) Production (in 2005/6) ran about 80 million oz/yr. Just over 1.5% impact to total supply, so you are right in that observation.  On the other hand, the limited amount out here, means that if everyone decided to put their wealth in gold, it would be done by driving the price to bubblicious levels.  One can study this all day, and parse out how much is in investment form (as compared to jewelry, etc) and realize that a few trillion dollars in value pales in comparison to the wealth of the US alone, let alone the world. Half the world can't buy two oz if they tried.  Of course there's pressure to reopen mines that had costs pushing $800/oz. Understand that the supply of $300 gold is long gone. As the easy gold has been mined, and cost goes up, there's a point where mines close. But as the price of gold trades at these levels, the mines that couldn't produce at $600 are now opening.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Why is property investment good if properties de-valuate over time?[/INST]
pred:
Property investment can be a good strategy even if properties de-value over time, for several reasons:

1. Long-term appreciation: While property values may fluctuate in the short term, historically, real estate has appreciated over the long term. This means that even if the value of a property decreases in the short term, it is likely to increase in value over a longer period, providing a long-term profit for investors.
2. Rent income: While the value of a property may decrease, the rental income generated by the property can provide a steady stream of income for investors. This can help offset any losses in value and provide a positive cash flow.
3. Leveraging: Real estate investors can leverage their investment by using financing options, such as mortgages. This allows investors to control larger properties with a lower amount of their own capital, potentially increasing their overall returns.
4. Diversification: Property investment can provide a diversification benefit to an investor's portfolio. Real estate can behave differently than other asset classes, such as stocks or bonds, and can help reduce overall portfolio risk.
5. Inflation protection: Real estate values can increase with inflation, which means that even if the value of a property decreases in nominal terms, it can still provide a hedge against inflation.
6. Tax benefits
answers: Real estate is not a good investment.  In fact, it's easy to make a case for it being the worst possible investment imaginable: Imagine over a cup or coffee or a glass of wine we get to talking   about investments. Then maybe one of us, let’s say you, says: “Hey I’ve got an idea. We’re always talking about good investments.   What if we came up with the worst possible investment we can   construct? What might that look like?” Well, let’s see now (pulling out our lined yellow pad), let’s make a   list. To be really terrible: -- Why Your House Is A Terrible Investment There are plenty of good reasons to own a home, but the key word there is "home".  Owning housing as an investment property is a horrible idea, and anyone who does it, especially right now with as bubbly as the market is looking again, (or, better put, still, since the last bubble never did fully pop and clear out the underlying systemic instability,) is an idiot. And even after the current housing market bubble pops, it's likely to remain a bad idea for decades.  We're never getting the early 2000s back, for basic supply-and-demand reasons: with the Baby Boom generation retiring, aging and dying off, they're not likely to do much more home-buying, and no generation after them is as big as they are, which means a glut of oversupply and weak demand for the entirety of the foreseeable future.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Can I buy a new house before selling my current house?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I must advise you that it is possible to buy a new house before selling your current house, but it may not be the best financial decision for you. Here are some factors to consider:

Pros:

1. Flexibility: Buying a new house before selling your current one gives you the flexibility to choose the house that best suits your needs and budget.
2. Timing: If you're concerned about the timing of selling your current house, buying a new one beforehand can give you more control over the process.
3. Financing: If you're unable to sell your current house quickly enough, buying a new one can help you avoid the financial burden of owning two homes.

Cons:

1. Double Mortgage Payments: Buying a new house before selling your current one means you'll have two mortgage payments to make each month, which can put a strain on your finances.
2. Paying Two Closing Costs: You'll need to pay closing costs for both properties, which can be expensive and may not be worth it if you're unable to sell your current house quickly.
3. Blindly Overpaying: If you buy a new house without selling your current one, you may end up overpaying for the new property, which can lead to financial
answers: I sold my house and had been in the market looking for a replacement house for over 6 months after I sold it. I found someone willing to give me a short term, 3 month lease, with a month to month after that, at an equitable rate, as renters were scarcer than buyers.By the time I found a house, there were bidding wars as surplus had declined (can be caused seasonally), and it was quite difficult to get my new house. However, appraisers help this to a degree because whatever the seller wants, is not necessarily what they get, even if you offer it. I offered $10k over asking just to get picked out of the large group bidding on the house. Once the appraisal came in at $10k below my offer, I was able to buy the house at what I expected. Of course I had to be prepared if it came in higher, but I did my homework and knew pretty much what the house was worth. The mortgage is the same as the lease I had, the house is only 10 years' old and has a 1 year warranty on large items that could go wrong. In the 3 months I've been in the house, I have gained nearly $8k in equity....and will have a tax writeoff of about $19,000 off an income off a salary of $72,000, giving me taxable income of $53,000... making by tax liability go down about $4600. If I am claiming 0 dependents I will get back about $5,000 this year versus breaking even.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can potentially affect your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, the account is typically closed and a new card is issued with new numbers. This can have an impact on your credit utilization ratio, which is a key factor in determining your credit score.

The credit utilization ratio is the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you. Keeping this ratio low (ideally below 30%) can help improve your credit score. When a credit card is closed and replaced, the old account may be considered "closed" or "delinquent" on your credit report, which can temporarily lower your credit score.

However, the effect on your credit score will depend on various factors, including the length of time the account was open, your payment history, and the number of other credit accounts you have. If you have a long history of timely payments and good credit habits, the impact may be minimal.

It's important to keep in mind that the new account on your credit report will have new account numbers, which means that the credit score impact may depend on the context of your overall credit profile. If you have a small number of credit accounts and the replaced card had a significant portion of your available credit, the new account may not have a significant impact on your credit score.

To minimize the
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

It's a good idea to consult with a financial advisor or tax professional to ensure you understand the tax implications of your transfer.

Leaving the original personal pension open after transferring money to a SIPP is possible, but it's important to understand the implications of doing so. If you leave the
answers: Yes it's entirely possible; see below.  If you can't find anything on transfers out (partial or otherwise) on anyone's site it's because they don't want to give anyone ideas. I have successfully done exactly what you're proposing earlier this year, transferring most of the value from my employer's group personal pension scheme - also Aviva! - to a much lower-cost SIPP.  The lack of any sign of movement by Aviva to post-RDR "clean priced" charge-levels on funds was the final straw for me.  My only regret is that I didn't do it sooner!  Transfer paperwork was initiated from the SIPP end but I was careful to make clear to HR people and Aviva's rep (or whatever group-scheme/employee benefits middleman organization he was from) that I was not exiting the company scheme and expected my employee and matching employer contributions to continue unchanged (and that I'd not be happy if some admin mess up led to me missing a month's contributions). There's a bit more on the affair in a thread here.  Aviva's rep did seem to need a bit of a prod to finally get it to happen.  With hindsight my original hope of an in-specie transfer does seem naive, but the out-of-the-market time was shorter and less scary than anticipated. Just in case you're unaware of it, Monevator's online broker list is an excellent resource to help decide who you might use for a SIPP; cheapest choice depends on level of funds and what you're likely to hold in it and how often you'll trade.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How is your credit score related to credit utilization?[/INST]
pred:
Credit score and credit utilization are closely related concepts in the world of personal finance. Your credit score is a numerical representation of how likely you are to repay your debts on time, based on information in your credit report. Credit utilization, on the other hand, refers to the amount of available credit you are using compared to the total credit limit on your accounts.

The relationship between credit score and credit utilization is as follows:

1. High credit utilization can negatively impact your credit score: If you are using a large portion of your available credit, it can make lenders hesitant to extend new credit to you, or they may view you as a higher credit risk. A general rule of thumb is to keep your credit utilization below 30% to maintain a good credit score.
2. Low credit utilization can positively impact your credit score: Using less than 30% of your available credit can help improve your credit score, as it demonstrates responsible credit behavior. The lower your credit utilization, the better it is for your credit score.
3. Credit score is influenced by the types of accounts you have: The types of accounts you have, such as credit cards, loans, and mortgages, can also affect your credit score. For example, having a mix of different types of accounts can help improve your credit score, while having too many new accounts or accounts in collections
answers: Curious, why are you interested in building/improving your credit score? Is it better to use your card and pay off the bill completely every month? Yes. How is credit utiltization calculated?    Is it average utilization over the month, or total amount owed/credit_limit per month? It depends on how often your bank reports your balances to the reporting agencies. It can be daily, when your statement cycle closes, or some other interval. How does credit utilization affect your score?  Closest to zero without actually being zero is best. This translates to making some charges, even $1 so your statement shows a balance each statement that you pay off. This shows as active use. If you pay off your balance before the statement closes, then it can sometimes be reported as inactive/unused. Is too much a bad thing?  Yes. Is too little a bad thing? Depends. Being debt free has its advantages... but if your goal is to raise your credit score, then having a low utilization rate is a good metric. Less than 7% utilization seems to be the optimal level.  "Last year we started using a number, not as a recommendation, but as a fact that most of the people with really high FICO scores have credit utilization rates that are 7 percent or lower," Watts said. Read more: http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/how-to-bump-up-your-credit-score.aspx Remember that on-time payment is the most important factor. Second is how much you owe. Third is length of credit history. Maintain these factors in good standing and you will improve your score: http://www.myfico.com/CreditEducation/WhatsInYourScore.aspx

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Credit card issued against my express refusal; What action can I take?[/INST]
pred:
If a credit card is issued against your express refusal, it may be a case of unauthorized use or identity theft. In this situation, you have several options to consider:

1. Contact the credit card issuer: Reach out to the credit card company's customer service department and explain the situation. They may have already received a report of unauthorized use and can assist you in resolving the issue.
2. Report the issue to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC): The FTC is responsible for enforcing federal laws related to identity theft and fraud. You can file a complaint with the FTC online or by calling their Identity Theft Hotline at 1-877-438-4338.
3. Place a fraud alert: Contact one of the three major credit reporting agencies (Experian, TransUnion, or Equifax) to place a fraud alert on your credit report. This will notify potential creditors that your credit card was issued without your consent and require them to take extra steps to verify your identity before extending credit.
4. Consider a credit freeze: A credit freeze prevents any new accounts from being opened in your name without your explicit permission. This can be a more effective way to prevent further unauthorized use, but it may also cause some inconvenience in certain situations, such as when you need to
answers: I believe it is so.  It doesn't sound like they did anything outright illegal, just a pushy upsell.  You can complain to the bank manager.  If you want you can mention the employee by name (if you know who they are).  Ultimately, you can change banks.  From what you say it sounds like you are dissatisfied with this bank, so I think you should at least begin evaluating other banks and consider switching.  You can also let your current bank know you are planning to take all your money away from them specifically because of their poor customer service. You could consider filing a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau alleging that the bank engaged in some kind of deceptive marketing of their financial products.  Of course you can also file a complaint with something like the Better Business Bureau, or even just write a negative Yelp review.  But these actions won't really result in any penalty for the bank as a result of what they did in your specific case; they just express your dissatisfaction in a way that will be recorded and possibly made public (e.g., in a list of complaints) to protect future consumers. If you're really gung-ho and have time and money to burn, you could hire a lawyer and get legal advice about whether it is possible to sue the bank for fraud or misuse of your personal information.  Needless to say, I think this would be overkill for this situation.  I would just cancel the credit card, tell the bank you're dissatisfied, switch banks, and move on.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When a company declares a dividend, it is the responsibility of the investor to pay the applicable taxes on the dividend income.

In the United States, dividends are considered taxable income and are subject to federal income tax rates, as well as state and local taxes. The withholding tax rate for dividends is generally 28.7%, but this can vary depending on the investor's tax status and the type of dividend.

To account for these taxes, investors must typically file a tax return and report their dividend income. The IRS requires companies to withhold taxes on dividends paid to non-U.S. investors, and these withholdings are typically reported on a Form 1099-Divlaration of Stock Dividends.

It's worth noting that some companies may choose to withhold taxes on dividends paid to U.S. investors, particularly those who are subject to withholding taxes under the Internal Revenue Code. However, this is less common and typically only applies to certain types of dividends, such as those paid on preference stock.

In summary, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks do not include withheld taxes, and investors are responsible for paying the
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it possible to block previously authorized ACH access?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I can tell you that it is generally not possible to permanently block previously authorized ACH (Automated Clearing House) access once it has been granted. ACH is a electronic payment network that enables financial institutions to transfer funds between accounts, and once an account holder has approved an ACH transfer, the funds are typically released and cannot be recalled.

However, there may be certain circumstances where an account holder can request to temporarily or permanently suspend their ACH access. For example, if you are experiencing financial difficulties or are a victim of fraud, you may be able to work with your bank to temporarily suspend ACH transactions.

Additionally, if you have previously authorized an ACH transfer but wish to reverse it, you may be able to do so by contacting the payee's bank and requesting a reversal. However, this process can take several days or weeks, and there may be fees associated with reversing an ACH transfer.

It's important to note that ACH transactions are final once they are processed, so it's important to carefully review and confirm any ACH transactions before they are processed. If you have any concerns about an ACH transaction, you should contact your bank as soon as possible to dispute the transaction and request a reversal.

In summary, while it may be possible to temporarily or permanently suspend A
answers: I had a similar situation a while ago, and here's what I learned: What are our options here to ensure that this company can't retry to take our money again via ACH? Close existing account and create a new one that has different account number? Yes. As a temporary solution keep ~$0 balance in the account so that their request for $840 can't be fulfilled? However, would our bank incur any fees because of insufficient funds each time the other company tries to charge us again? Bad idea. You may incur penalties for returned payment, or the bank may honor the payment and charge you overdraft fees. Provide to our bank the service termination notice that proves that we   are not in business with the other company anymore and effectively   block them. However, termination notice has only our signature Bank doesn't care. ACH withdrawal is akin to a check. The assumption is that the other side has entitlement. You can put stop payment once its processed and try to reverse it claiming fraud, but the end result will be #1: you'll end up getting a new account set up, while they try to recover the money. This is one of the reasons I'm reluctant allowing standing ACH authorizations any more. Generally, the American banking system is very much geared against the consumers, and in many ways is very retarded. In a more advanced countries (which is almost any other country than the US), the standing withdrawal authorization goes through your bank and can be revoked.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Does the low CAD positively or negatively impact Canadian Investors?[/INST]
pred:
A low Canadian dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors.

Positive impacts:

1. Export-oriented businesses: A low CAD can make Canadian exports more competitive in foreign markets, potentially leading to increased sales and revenue for businesses that rely on exports. This can be especially beneficial for companies in industries such as automotive, aerospace, and agriculture.
2. Tourism: A low CAD can make Canada more attractive to international tourists, leading to increased tourism revenue and economic growth in sectors such as hospitality and travel.
3. imports: A low CAD can make imports cheaper, which can lead to lower prices for consumers and increased competition in retail markets.

Negative impacts:

1. Reduced purchasing power: A low CAD can reduce the purchasing power of Canadian investors, making them less competitive in foreign markets and potentially reducing the value of their investments.
2. Inflation: A low CAD can lead to higher inflation rates, as imported goods become more expensive. This can erode the purchasing power of Canadians and reduce the value of their investments.
3. Interest rates: A low CAD can lead to higher interest rates, as central banks try to combat inflation and maintain economic
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Should I Use an Investment Professional?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I must advise you that utilizing an investment professional can be a valuable decision for your financial well-being. An investment professional, such as a financial advisor or wealth manager, can provide you with personalized investment advice and help you make informed decisions about your investments.

Here are some reasons why you may want to consider working with an investment professional:

1. Expertise: Investment professionals have extensive knowledge and experience in the financial industry. They can help you identify investment opportunities that align with your financial goals and risk tolerance, and provide guidance on how to manage your investments.
2. Objectivity: An investment professional can provide you with unbiased investment advice, free from conflicts of interests. They can help you make decisions based on your financial goals, rather than on the sales pitch of a particular product or service.
3. Time-saving: Investing can be time-consuming and complex, especially for those who are new to investing. An investment professional can take care of the legwork, researching investment opportunities and managing your portfolio on your behalf.
4. Personalized service: A good investment professional will take the time to understand your unique financial situation and goals, and provide personalized recommendations tailored to your needs.
5. Accountability: An investment professional can help
answers: Yes.  The investment world is extremely fast-paced and competitive. There are loads of professional traders with supercomputers working day in and day out to make smarter, faster trade decisions than you. If you try to compete with them, there’s a better than fair chance you’ll lose precious time and money, which kind of defeats the purpose. A good wealth manager: In short, they can save you time and money and help you take the most advantage of your current savings. Or, you can think about it in terms of cost. Most wealth managers charge an annual fee (as a % of the amount invested) for their services. This fee can range anywhere from close to zero, to 0.75% depending upon how sophisticated the strategy is that the money will be invested in, and what kind of additional services they have to offer. Investing in the S&P500 on the behalf of the investor shouldn’t need a fee, but investing in a smart beta or an alpha strategy, that generates returns independent of the market’s movement and certainly commands a fee. But how does one figure if that fee is justified? It is really simple. What is the risk-adjusted performance of the strategy? What is the Sharpe ratio? Large successful funds like Renaissance Technologies and Citadel can charge 3% in addition to 30% of profits because even after that their returns are much better than the market. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the point of the stock market? What is it for, and why might someone want to trade or invest?[/INST]
pred:
The stock market serves as a platform for companies to raise capital and for investors to buy and sell ownership shares in those companies. The primary function of the stock market is to provide a mechanism for companies to access the capital they need to grow and expand their businesses, while allowing investors to participate in the financial success of those companies.

When a company wants to raise money, it can issue stocks, which are essentially shares of ownership in the company. Investors can then buy these shares, providing the company with the capital it needs. In return, the investors become partial owners of the company and are entitled to a share of the company's profits in the form of dividends.

Trading or investing in the stock market allows companies and individuals to:

1. Raise capital: Companies can raise funds by issuing stocks or bonds to the public or to institutional investors, such as pension funds or mutual funds.
2. Diversify portfolios: By investing in stocks, individuals can spread their risk across different asset classes, such as stocks, bonds, and real estate, to reduce their overall risk and increase potential returns.
3. Potential for long-term growth: Stocks have historically provided higher returns over the long-term compared to other asset classes, making them an attractive option for long-term investors.
4
answers: In finance, form is function, and while a reason for a trade could be anything, but since the result of a trade is a change in value, it could be presumed that one seeks to receive a change in value. Stock company There may have been more esoteric examples, but currently, possession of a company (total ownership of its' assets actually) is delineated by percentage or a glorified "banknote" frequently called a "share".  Percentage companies are usually sole proprietorship and partnerships, but partnerships can now trade in "units".  Share companies are usually corporations. With shares, a company can be divided into almost totally indistinguishable units.  This allows for more flexible ownership, so individuals can trade them without having to change the company contract. Considering the ease of trade, it could be assumed that common stock contract provisions were formulated to provide for such an ease. Motivation to trade This could be anything, but it seems those with the largest ownership of common stock have lots of wealth, so it could be assumed that people at least want to own stocks to own wealth. Shorting might be a little harder to reason, but I personally assume that the motivation to trade is still to increase wealth. Social benefit of the stock market Assuming that ownership in a company is socially valuable and that the total value of ownership is proportional to the social value provided, the social benefit of a stock market is that it provided the means to scale ownership through convenience, speed, and reliability.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Should I always pay my credit at the last day possible to maximize my savings interest?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I must advise you that paying your credit card bill at the last day possible to maximize your savings interest is not always the best financial strategy. While it may seem like a good idea to avoid paying interest charges, there are some potential drawbacks to consider:

1. Late fees: If you pay your credit card bill after the due date, you may incur late fees, which can negate any savings from avoiding interest charges.
2. Credit score impact: Making only the minimum payment or paying your bill late can have a negative impact on your credit score, which can lead to higher interest rates on future credit products and other financial obligations.
3. Opportunity cost: By paying your credit card bill at the last minute, you may be missing out on other financial opportunities, such as investing your money or paying off higher-interest debt.

Instead of waiting until the last day possible to pay your credit card bill, consider the following strategies:

1. Pay more than the minimum: To avoid interest charges altogether, try to pay more than the minimum payment on your credit card bill each month. This will help you pay off your balance faster and save on interest charges.
2. Automate your payments: Set up automatic payments for your credit card bill to ensure it's paid on time each month. This
answers: Mostly ditto to Dillip Sarwate. Let me just add: I don't know how you're making your payments, whether through the biller's web site, your bank's web site, by mail, in person, etc. But whatever the mechanism, if there is a chance that waiting until the due date to pay may mean that you will miss the due date: don't. The cost of a late payment charge is likely to far exceed any interest you would collect on your savings. Bear in mind that we are talking pennies here. I don't know how much the monthly bills that we are discussing here come to. Say it's $3,000. I think that would be a lot for most people. You say you're getting 3.6% on your savings. So if, on the average, you pay a bill 2 weeks later than you might have, you're getting an extra 2 / 52 x 3.6% x $3,000 in interest, or $4 per month. I think the last time I paid a late fee on a credit card it was $35, so if you make one mistake every 8 months and end up getting a late fee it will outweigh any savings.  Personally, I pay most of my bills through either my bank's web site or the biller's web site. I schedule all payments when I get a paycheck, and I generally try to schedule them for 1 week before the due date, so there's plenty of breathing room.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I must first emphasize that stop-loss orders are a common and widely used risk management tool in financial markets. However, whether they are safe or not depends on various factors, which I will outline below.

A stop-loss order is an order to sell a security when its price falls below a certain level (known as the stop price). The primary purpose of a stop-loss order is to limit potential losses by automatically closing a position when it reaches a certain price level. For example, if you buy 100 shares of XYZ stock at $50 and set a stop-loss order at $40, the broker will sell the shares when the price falls to $40, limiting your losses to $10 per share.

Now, are stop-loss orders safe? The answer is complex, and it depends on several factors. Here are some points to consider:

1. Market volatility: Stop-loss orders are most effective in highly volatile markets, where price swings are significant. In such markets, stop-loss orders can help limit losses by automatically closing positions when the price falls to a certain level. However, in calm markets, stop-loss orders may not be as effective, as price movements are less pronounced.
2. Price slippage: When a stop-loss order is triggered, the broker may execute the sale of
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes in the United States. This is known as "utilizing a tax loss carryforward."

When a taxpayer experiences a net loss on their investments, they can deduct that loss from their taxable income in the current year. Any unused portion of the loss can be carried over to future years and used to offset capital gains in those years. For example, if a taxpayer has a $10,000 capital loss in one year and only $2,000 of that loss can be used to offset capital gains in that year, the remaining $8,000 can be carried over to the next year.

The tax loss carryforward can be used to offset capital gains from the sale of investments, such as stocks, mutual funds, or real estate. It can also be used to offset capital gains from other sources, such as the sale of a business or inheritance. The carryforward can be used indefinitely, but it must be used within a certain timeframe. For example, if the loss was incurred in 2018, the taxpayer has until 2028 to use the carryforward to offset capital gains.

It's important to note that the tax loss carryforward is subject to certain limitations and may be subject to phase-out rules
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How does high frequency trading work if money isn't available for 2-3 days after selling?[/INST]
pred:
High frequency trading (HFT) is a trading strategy that uses powerful computers and sophisticated algorithms to execute trades at very high speeds, often in fractions of a second. HFTs use various strategies to exploit small price discrepancies in financial markets, such as statistical arbitrage, market making, and trend following.

One common question about HFT is how it can work when money isn't available for 2-3 days after selling. The answer lies in the way HFTs manage their risk and use various financial instruments to ensure they have the necessary funds to execute trades.

HFTs typically use a combination of margin loans and derivative instruments, such as futures, options, and swaps, to finance their trades. Margin loans are provided by brokers or other financial institutions, and they allow HFTs to borrow money to purchase securities. The borrower must make regular interest payments on the loan, and the loan must be repaid in full at the end of the borrowing period.

Derivative instruments, on the other hand, allow HFTs to gain exposure to financial markets without actually owning the underlying assets. For example, a HFT might buy a futures contract on the S&P 500 index, which gives them exposure to the underlying stocks without
answers: As previously answered, the solution is margin. It works like this: You deposit e.g. 1'000 USD at your trading company. They give you a margin of e.g. 1:100, so you are allowed to trade with 100'000 USD.  Let's say you buy 5'000 pieces of a stock at $20 USD (fully using your 100'000 limit), and the price changes to $20.50 . Your profit is 5000* $0.50 = $2'500. Fast money? If you are lucky. Let's say before the price went up to 20.50, it had a slight dip down to $19.80. Your loss was 5000* $0.2 = 1'000$. Wait! You had just 1000 to begin with: You'll find an email saying "margin call" or "termination notice": Your shares have been sold at $19.80 and you are out of business. The broker willingly gives you this credit, since he can be sure he won't loose a cent. Of course you pay interest for the money you are trading with, but it's only for minutes. So to answer your question: You don't care when you have "your money" back, the trading company will always be there to give you more as long as you have deposit left. (I thought no one should get margin explained without the warning why it is a horrible idea to full use the ridiculous high margins some broker offer. 1:10 might or might not be fine, but 1:100 is harakiri.)

prompt:

My medical bill went to a collection agency. Can I pay it directly to the hospital?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, you can definitely pay your medical bill directly to the hospital even after it has been sent to a collection agency. Here are some steps you can follow:

1. Contact the hospital: Reach out to the hospital's billing department to inform them that you want to pay your medical bill directly. They can provide you with the necessary instructions and may be able to work out a payment plan with you.
2. Determine the balance owed: Find out the current balance of your medical bill and confirm that it includes all the charges incurred during your hospital stay.
3. Make the payment: You can either pay the bill in full or set up a payment plan with the hospital. You may be able to make the payment over the phone, online, or in person at the hospital's billing office.
4. Follow up: After you've made the payment, follow up with the hospital to ensure that your payment has been processed and that the collection agency has been notified.

It's important to note that if the bill has already been sent to a collection agency, it may impact your credit score. However, paying the bill directly to the hospital can help you avoid additional fees and penalties associated with collections.

Additionally, you can also contact the collection agency directly and ask them to forward your payment to the hospital. They may have a process in place for handling
answers: Short Answer Collections agencies and the businesses they collect for are two different animals. If you don't want this to hurt your credit I suggest you deal directly with the hospital. Pay the bill, but prior to paying it get something in writing that specifically says that this will not be reported onto your credit. That is of course if the hospital even lets you pay them directly. Usually once something is sold to a collections company it's written off.  Long Answer Credit reports are kind of a nightmare to deal with. The hospital just wants their money so they will sell debt off to collections companies. The collections companies want to make money on the debt they've bought so they will do what ever it takes to get it out of you, including dinging your credit report. The credit bureaus are the biggest nightmare to deal with of all. Once something is reported on your credit history they do little to nothing to remove it. You can report it online but this is a huge mistake because when you report online you wave your rights to sue the credit bureaus if they don't investigate the matter properly. This of course leads to massive amounts of claims being under investigated.  So what are your options once something hits your credit history? I know this all sounds bleak but the reason I go into such depth is that they likely have already reported it to the credit bureaus and you just don't see it reported yet. Good luck to you. Get a bottle of aspirin.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I can explain that a debt collector is allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report under certain circumstances.

A hard inquiry, also known as a "hard pull," occurs when a lender or creditor accesses your credit report to evaluate your creditworthiness for a loan or credit application. Debt collectors, who are entities or individuals hired to collect unpaid debts on behalf of creditors, may also perform hard inquiries on your credit report.

However, there are limits to how often debt collectors can perform hard inquiries on your credit report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), a debt collector can only make up to three hard inquiries on your credit report within a 12-month period. This means that if you have multiple debts or debt accounts being collected by different debt collectors, they can only perform up to three hard inquiries combined within that time frame.

It's worth noting that debt collectors may still be able to access your credit report for legitimate purposes, such as verifying the accuracy of your debt or determining your creditworthiness for a payment plan. However, they must follow the FCRA requirements regarding the frequency and purpose of their inquiries.

If you're concerned about the number of hard inquiries on your
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.
